info.description:
# Introduction
This is the new version of our API.

The API is now formalized and stable, and includes a significant subset of the entire feature set of the system.

We expect the new API to grow until it covers all of the functionality of the previous version. Also, keep in mind that we support older versions of our API for a period of time, and continue to provide backward compatibility.


## Overview
This document describes the Guardicore Centra REST API. The API complements the UI offering and provides programmatic access to all Centra functionality.

Users can build applications that read flow visibility data or security incident details, change the active segmentation policy and more.

All examples in this document assume an installed Guardicore Management server in `https://{management_server}`


## General
All POST methods assume an HTTP header: `Content-Type: application/json`

All timestamps are specified in milliseconds since epoch, UTC time.

Asset IDs are assigned (as UUIDs) by the Guardicore platform.

Some replies are paginated. You can browse the results by specifying start_at and max_results URL parameters. For example, to get objects 40-59 of the Assets list, query:
`https://{management_server}/api/v3.0/assets?start_at=40&max_results=20`


## Authentication
Authentication with REST API is done using JWT.

Obtain a token by sending a POST request to `/api/v3.0/authenticate`, with the following body:
`{"username": "<username>", "password": "<password>"}`

The response will be `access_token: <token>`

Use the returned token in subsequent requests in one of the following methods:
- You can include it as an HTTP URI argument, by appending `?token=<token>` to your request
- You can include an HTTP header in your request: `Authorization: bearer <token>`
info.title: Guardicore Centraâ„¢ Web API

get.description:
List all segmentation policy rules

The following filters are `any_side` filters for the `source` and `destination` of the rule.
Only one of them can be used in a time: * **assets:**
format: `assets=`
example: `assets=461bf3a5-22b0-4693-8e8e-fc89807f39cc` * **subnets:**
format: `subnets=`
example: `subnets=10.0.10.0/24` * **Internet/NonInternet:**
format: `address_classification=`
example: `address_classification=Private` * **labels:**
format: `labels=`
example: `labels=1219d8a5-6902-4c48-a2d4-82f1806605cc` * **label groups:**
format: `label_groups=`
example: `label_groups=1219d8a5-6902-4c48-a2d4-82f1806605cc` * **user groups:**
format: `user_groups=`
example: `user_groups=1219d8a5-6902-4c48-a2d4-82f1806605cc` * **processes:**
format: `processes=`
example: `processes=apt-get` * **domains:**
format: `domains=`
example: `domains=*.github.com` Any of the filters (except for `address_classification`) can also accept a list of terms, separated by `|`, which implies an "or" condition between the items. Any of the terms in the `label` filter can additionally be given as a list of sub-terms, separated by `>`, which implies an "and" condition between the sub-terms.

Examples:
* Find all rules from / to internet to one of two labels:
`?address_classification=Internet` * Find all rules from / to two "or" labels:
`?labels=2afc02e5-a3f0-45b0-a161-9db753d14900|8464e957-e082-4eb4-94fd-c9888c62f739` * Find all rules from / to three "or" and "and" labels:
`?labels=2afc02e5-a3f0-45b0-a161-9db753d14900|550623e8-bd2a-490c-bfaa-96b602f9a52c>8464e957-e082-4eb4-94fd-c9888c62f739`

value.description: Data needed to display value (of the former key). For type "text" - maximum 2000 chars. For type "rule" - a valid UUID.For type "asset-id" - a valid asset id.For type "ip" - a valid ip address.For type "domain" - a valid domain.
If type is VM - vm_id, if type is IP - the ip address

expand_node.description: The expand list indicates which nodes in the filtered graph should be expanded in order to get their full details. For example, a VM node needs to be "expand:true" to see process information.                    The expand list should be comprised of item IDs, and each one with "expand" action and the node type.

group_by.description: A comma-separated labels keys to group assets by label hierarchy

disable_autogc.description: Do not automatically select a Global Catalog (use only if it gives errors)

customer_folder.description: Customer folder in GCS to which the result will be stored

global_catalog.description: File containing computer FQDNs to use as allowlist for any computer based methods

workers.description: Number of workers for computer enumeration (default: 10)

collection_method.description: One of the supported Python BloodHound methods. Possible options: Group, LocalAdmin, Session, Trusts, Default (all previous), DCOnly (no computer connections), DCOM, RDP, PSRemote, LoggedOn, Container, ObjectProps, ACL, All (all except LoggedOn). You can specify more than one by separating them with a comma. (default: Default)

dns_tcp.description: Use TCP instead of UDP for DNS queries

auth_method.description: {auto,ntlm,kerberos} Authentication methods. Force Kerberos or NTLM only or use auto for Kerberos with NTLM fallback

nameserver.description: Alternative name server to use for queries

aes_key.description: AES key to use for Kerberos Authentication (128 or 256 bits)

status.description: Status of attempt to stop BloodHound scan
